frameDefinitions: An Entity changes from a Prior_state to a Post_state in a sequence that follows a pre-defined plan, expectation, or model of change.
An individual or group (Practitioner) or a part of their work life (Work) is defined professionally by the Activity that they typically engage in.
A Speaker communicates a message stating an Item's membership in a Category, i.e., asserts that the Item has the defining characteristics of the Category.
A Cognizer faces a choice on some Issue.
A Cognizer construes an Item as belonging to a certain Category.
An Agent occupies a Role in some institution.
frameExamples: Their offensive armament has <t>developed</t> from short range missiles to long-range ballistic weaponry in a relatively short period .
Chris was in the construction <t>industry</t> for 20 years before coming to GSCM.
He <t>depicted</t> his involvement as merely peripheral.
Dave Hayes <t>wavered</t> about moving to California because so many of his friends are in Baltimore.
You 've already <t>stereotyped</t> me as a bimbo, have n't you?
Chris <t>served</t> as chairman of the boardfor one year.
listRoleDefinitions: The object that undergoes change.
The time at which the progress occurs.
The location where the Progress occurs.
An activity that defines a group of people in their professional capacity.
The individual, group, or organization  that engages in the <fen>Activity</fen> as part of their profession.
A physical or abstract entity that is characteristically associated with the <fen>Activity</fen>.
A phase of a <fen>Practitioner</fen>'s career that is spent engaged in an <fen>Activity</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Practitioner</fen> engages in the <fen>Activity</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Practitioner</fen> engages in the <fen>Activity</fen>.
The individual that communicates the message concerning the <fen>Category</fen> of an <fen>Item</fen>.
The class of entities with characteristics that match those of the <fen>Item</fen> according to the portrayal of the <fen>Speaker</fen>.
The entity that the <fen>Speaker</fen> portrays as belonging to a <fen>Category</fen>.
The piece of text in which a <fen>Speaker</fen> communicates their categorization of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes a characterization of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Speaker</fen> characterizes the <fen>Item</fen>
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person who repeatedly changes their mind about which of the <fen>Options</fen> to choose.
The <fen>Options</fen> are the alternative courses of action or the alternative physical or concrete entities that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> can choose from.
The <fen>Issue</fen> is a question about a course of action or a choice between items.

When there is an explicitly separate construal of the <fen>Options</fen>, <fen>Option_1</fen> is the first-mentioned alternative, typically in the form of a from-PP. When it is clear that  the <fen>Cognizer</fen> actually acted on their choice, <fen>Option_1</fen> is the alternative they embraced first before pursuing <fen>Option_2</fen>.

When there is an explicitly separate construal of the <fen>Options</fen>, <fen>Option_2</fen> is the second-mentioned alternative, typically in the form of a to-PP. When it is clear that  the <fen>Cognizer</fen> actually acted on their choice, <fen>Option_2</fen> is the alternative they embraced after abandoning <fen>Option_1</fen>.
This role denotes the <fen>Time</fen> interval during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> keeps changing their mind about which of the <fen>Options</fen> to select.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> keeps changing their mind between the <fen>Options</fen> that present themselves.
This is the person who performs an act of categorization. Typically, this frame element is expressed as an External Argument.
This is the entity which is construed or treated by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> as being an instance of a particular <fen>Category</fen>. Typically, the <fen>Item</fen> is expressed as an Object.

This frame element expresses a general type or class of which the <fen>Item</fen> is considered an instance. Typically, it is expressed in a prepositional phrase headed by <ment>as</ment> or <ment>under</ment>.

This frame element expresses properties of the <fen>Item</fen> which is used as a basis for categorization. <fen>Criteria</fen> are the general dimensions along which <fen>Item</fen>s can potentially differ from one another and hence, fall into different <fen>Category</fen>s. For example, a paint sample can be classified <ment>by color</ment> or <ment>by finish (matte or gloss)</ment>; if they are classified by color, one can be classified <ment>as orange</ment> and another <ment>as red</ment>. The <fen>Criteria</fen> role is typically expressed as a PP headed by <ment>by</ment>, or as a complex PP of the form <ment>on the basis of...</ment>:
This Frame Element marks expressions that indicate when a certain Categorization was made.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the entity that occpuies the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Role</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> occupies.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> served in the <fen>Role</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Agent</fen> served in the <fen>Role</fen>.
listRoleExamples: Advances <fex>in marketing techniques</fex> have since rendered it obsolete.
<fex>When</fex> did the X-wing progress beyond the drawing board?
One of the companies we are presently invested in is Boral, which is in the <fex>building</fex> sector.
These companies who have their roots in either the 19th or early 20th century have been in <fex>oil</fex> all their existence.
<fex>My most recent job</fex> was in the construction industry.
However, <fex>'A Brief History of Medicine'</fex> characterizes influenza as the most deadly plague, overall.
<fex>I</fex> went back and forth over whether to post it or not, but the fact is that this blog is as much for you as it is for me.
In the late 1890s Carnegie vacillated <fex>between wanting to dominate the steel industry and wanting to sell out</fex>.
Editors go back and forth on a daily basis <fex>about what gets in the paper</fex>.
You've waffled <fex>from one explanation</fex> to another.
The heroine waffled from one plan <fex>to another</fex> and all of them were way out in 'left field'.

Here, however, the Romeros had provided some assurance to Ryan's mother of care,
although the court <fex>later</fex> waffled upon how much supervision was guaranteed
Do they know better than us that our dithering <fex>at the UN</fex> gave Saddam time to hide, destroy, and shuffle his weapons programs?
<fex>Kim</fex> categorized the books under fiction. <fex>Kim</fex> categorized them on the basis of genre.
The students were categorized <fex>on the basis of their test scores</fex>.
<fex>20 years ago</fex> people would consider this as nothing unusual

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The Evolution of the Fire Service EMS Vehicle
the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards (FMVSS)
A History of the Military Ambulance
